Peter, yes this is all true.  Reil and Husbands did go on to found 
Natural=
Motion.  I agree with you that there is a nice new opportunity 
with applyi=
ng CPPNs to CTRNNs.  I look forward to seeing how your 
project goes.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wr=
ote:
>
> Ken, I have to mention that Tyler was inspired by Torsten Reil and=
 
> Phil Husbands about their work on the same stuff. They used fully 
> co=
nnected CTRNNs. No crossover and fixed genome size. Well, it is 
> just lik=
e the opposite to the NEAT philosophy about the problem. I 
> examined his =
.ne file, and he made the add_link and add_node 
> probabilities to 0.00. :=
) 
> Well this is NEAT in the weight-range sense only :)  
> What about top=
ology? That was not mentioned anywhere. 
> In fact, Reil and Husbands are t=
he people founded NaturalMotion? :) 
> I know that a CTRNN can generate any=
 dynamic behaviour, but putting 
> it into HyperNEAT's hands is changing th=
e whole thing! Now I can 
> specify any time constant range and so on. I do=
n't care about 
> mutation powers anymore. This is handled by the activatio=
n 
functions 
> and the scale factor I specify. 
> The power of this indire=
ction is getting to our view. I see that 
> CTRNN networks exhibit patterns=
 as complex as their CPPN is. Well, 
> this is cool! 
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> --=

er and Steve, the way I would approach this problem is to 
start

the simplest possible model and get it working before moving

e complex or biologically plausible ones.  It's interesting to 
> > note th=
at Tyler Streeter evolved his biped with no inputs!  He 
was 
> > trying to=

> inputs 
> > could p=
roduce a temporal walking pattern.  Of course that makes 
the 
> > problem =
quite difficult, and giving some feedback (i.e. inputs) 
> makes 
> > the p=
roblem easier.  However, too many inputs could tip the 
> > difficulty back=
 in the other direction.  In any case, my approach 
> to 
> > a hard proble=
m is always to first see if I can do the easiest 
> version 
> > of it.
> >=

obably is mainly hand-coded.  They started out using CTRNNs but

oved on the scripting and other things as Peter mentioned.

 are a very difficult target to match with evolution alone.

 way, thanks for the encouraging words on NEAT and 
HyperNEAT.
